Hilbert spaces

Let D‾={z∈C∣∣z∣≤1}\cl{\D} = \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} \leq 1}D={z∈C∣∣z∣≤1} and consider the (complex) Hilbert space

H={f ⁣:D‾→C | f(z)=∑k=0∞f^(k)zk with ∥f∥2=∑k=0∞(1+k2)∣f^(k)∣2<∞}.\mathcal{H} = \set{\func{f}{\cl{\D}}{\C} \st f\p{z} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \hat{f}\p{k}z^k \text{ with } \norm{f}^2 = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \p{1 + k^2}\abs{\hat{f}\p{k}}^2 < \infty}.H={f:D→C∣∣​f(z)=k=0∑∞​f^​(k)zk with ∥f∥2=k=0∑∞​(1+k2)∣∣​f^​(k)∣∣​2<∞}.

  1. Prove that the linear function L ⁣:f↦f(1)L\colon f \mapsto f\p{1}L:f↦f(1) is bounded.

  2. Find the element g∈Hg \in \mathcal{H}g∈H representing LLL.

  3. Show that f↦Re⁡L(f)f \mapsto \Re{L\p{f}}f↦ReL(f) achieves its maximal value on the set

    B={f∈H | ∥f∥≤1 and f(0)=0},\mathcal{B} = \set{f \in \mathcal{H} \st \norm{f} \leq 1 \text{ and } f\p{0} = 0},B={f∈H∣∥f∥≤1 and f(0)=0},

    that this maximum occurs at a unique point, and determine this maximal value.
Solution.

  1. By Cauchy-Schwarz,

    ∣f(1)∣≤∑k=0∞∣f^(k)∣1+k2⋅11+k2≤(∑k=0∞(1+k2)∣f^(k)∣2)1/2(∑k=0∞11+k2)1/2=(∑k=0∞11+k2)1/2∥f∥,\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{1}} &\leq \sum_{k=0}^\infty \abs{\hat{f}\p{k}}\sqrt{1 + k^2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + k^2}} \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{k=0}^\infty \p{1 + k^2}\abs{\hat{f}\p{k}}^2}^{1/2} \p{\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2}}^{1/2} \\ &= \p{\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2}}^{1/2} \norm{f}, \end{aligned}∣f(1)∣​≤k=0∑∞​∣∣​f^​(k)∣∣​1+k2​⋅1+k2​1​≤(k=0∑∞​(1+k2)∣∣​f^​(k)∣∣​2)1/2(k=0∑∞​1+k21​)1/2=(k=0∑∞​1+k21​)1/2∥f∥,​

    and because the series converges, LLL is bounded.

  2. We assume that the inner product is given by

    ⟨f,g⟩=∑k=0∞f^(k)g^(k)‾(1+k2).\inner{f, g} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \hat{f}\p{k}\conj{\hat{g}\p{k}} \p{1 + k^2}.⟨f,g⟩=k=0∑∞​f^​(k)g^​(k)​(1+k2).

    If ggg represents LLL, then it must satisfy

    ⟨f,g⟩=f(1)  ⟺  ∑k=0∞f^(k)g^(k)‾(1+k2)=∑k=0∞f^(k)\inner{f, g} = f\p{1} \iff \sum_{k=0}^\infty \hat{f}\p{k}\conj{\hat{g}\p{k}} \p{1 + k^2} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \hat{f}\p{k}⟨f,g⟩=f(1)⟺k=0∑∞​f^​(k)g^​(k)​(1+k2)=k=0∑∞​f^​(k)

    for any f∈Hf \in \mathcal{H}f∈H. Thus, if we set

    g(z)=∑k=0∞zk1+k2,g\p{z} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{z^k}{1 + k^2},g(z)=k=0∑∞​1+k2zk​,

    then the identity is satisfied. This definition makes sense as the series converges on D‾\cl{\D}D, so it remains to show that g∈Hg \in \mathcal{H}g∈H by showing that ∥g∥<∞\norm{g} < \infty∥g∥<∞. But this is clear:

    ∥g∥2=∑k=0∞11+k2<∞,\norm{g}^2 = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2} < \infty,∥g∥2=k=0∑∞​1+k21​<∞,

    so g∈Hg \in \mathcal{H}g∈H and we are done.

  3. Observe that if 0<∥f∥<10 < \norm{f} < 10<∥f∥<1, then

    Re⁡L(f)<Re⁡L(f)∥f∥=Re⁡L(f∥f∥).\Re{L\p{f}} < \frac{\Re{L\p{f}}}{\norm{f}} = \Re{L\p{\frac{f}{\norm{f}}}}.ReL(f)<∥f∥ReL(f)​=ReL(∥f∥f​).

    Thus, if the maximum is attained, it must occur with ∥f∥=1\norm{f} = 1∥f∥=1. Also, notice that for z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C, Re⁡z≤∣z∣\Re{z} \leq \abs{z}Rez≤∣z∣, and the maximum is attained if and only if zzz is real. Thus, if there exists k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 such that f^(k)\hat{f}\p{k}f^​(k) is not real, then

    Re⁡f(1)=∑k=0∞Re⁡f^(k)<∑k=0∞∣f^(k)∣.\Re{f\p{1}} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \Re\hat{f}\p{k} < \sum_{k=0}^\infty \abs{\hat{f}\p{k}}.Ref(1)=k=0∑∞​Ref^​(k)<k=0∑∞​∣∣​f^​(k)∣∣​.

    Thus, if we replace f^(k)\hat{f}\p{k}f^​(k) with ∣f^(k)∣\abs{\hat{f}\p{k}}∣∣​f^​(k)∣∣​, then the resulting function is still in H\mathcal{H}H and gives a strictly larger value. Thus, the maximum must be attained by a function fff with f^(k)\hat{f}\p{k}f^​(k) real. Similarly, if we remove negative values of f^(k)\hat{f}\p{k}f^​(k), we get a strictly larger value, so the maximum also has non-negative coefficients. Hence, from now, we only need to consider fff with f^(k)≥0\hat{f}\p{k} \geq 0f^​(k)≥0 for all k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 and ∥f∥=1\norm{f} = 1∥f∥=1.

    Observe that with this restriction, Re⁡L(f)=f(1)\Re{L\p{f}} = f\p{1}ReL(f)=f(1). By the same argument as in (2), we also see that on B\mathcal{B}B, this functional is represented by

    g(z)=∑k=1∞zk1+k2,g\p{z} = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{z^k}{1 + k^2},g(z)=k=1∑∞​1+k2zk​,

    i.e., the same ggg as in (2), but with the constant term removed. Thus, by Cauchy-Schwarz,

    Re⁡f(1)=f(1)=⟨f,g⟩≤∥f∥∥g∥=∥g∥,\Re{f\p{1}} = f\p{1} = \inner{f, g} \leq \norm{f}\norm{g} = \norm{g},Ref(1)=f(1)=⟨f,g⟩≤∥f∥∥g∥=∥g∥,

    since ∥f∥=1\norm{f} = 1∥f∥=1. From here, we see that the maximum is attained uniquely by f=g∥g∥f = \frac{g}{\norm{g}}f=∥g∥g​, so it remains to show that this choice of fff is in B\mathcal{B}B.

    It's clear that ∥f∥=1\norm{f} = 1∥f∥=1, and

    f(0)=g(0)∥g∥=0f\p{0} = \frac{g\p{0}}{\norm{g}} = 0f(0)=∥g∥g(0)​=0

    by construction, so f∈Hf \in \mathcal{H}f∈H. Finally, the maximal value is given by

    g(1)∥g∥=(∑k=1∞11+k2)(∑k=1∞11+k2)−1/2=(∑k=1∞11+k2)1/2,\frac{g\p{1}}{\norm{g}} = \p{\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2}}\p{\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2}}^{-1/2} = \p{\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{1}{1 + k^2}}^{1/2},∥g∥g(1)​=(k=1∑∞​1+k21​)(k=1∑∞​1+k21​)−1/2=(k=1∑∞​1+k21​)1/2,

    which completes the proof.
